title: H1514 Get access to non public information by pivoting with graphql queries

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
Hi security team,

**Summary:** It is possible to pivot with queries to get access to information you shouldn't have access to according to docs located at https://help.shopify.com/en/api/graphql-admin-api/reference/queryroot

**Description:** I will try to write up all the ones I can find related to information disclosure where a user with only access to Apps can get from other parts of the store using the graphiql app.

* Example 1:
User with no home access can use locations query to find out store locations and address
{F360024}
It is also possible to use inventoryLevel(inventoryItemId) to get access to inventory without access

* Example 2:
Marketing activities with no marketing access
{F360044}
even though it is possible to ask for more this is the basic query I used. Note it doesn't say access denied.
`query{marketingActivities(first:100){edges{node{id,title, createdAt, budget{total{amount}}}}}}`

* Example 3:
Publications and api keys(I suspect app access makes you see api keys but still)
{F360060}
Query I used:
`query{publications(first: 100){edges{node{name, id, supportsFuturePublishing, app{apiKey}}}}}`

## Impact

This means the graphql can be used to disclose information about other parts of the store that a low permissions user shouldn't have access to.

Best,
Eray
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi security team,

Summary: It is possible to pivot with queries to get access to information you shouldn't have access to according to docs located at https://help.shopify.com/en/api/graphql-admin-api/reference/queryroot

Description: I will try to write up all the ones I can find related to information disclosure where a user with only access to Apps can get from other parts of the store using the graphiql app.

  • Example 1:
    User with no home access can use locations query to find out store locations and address

    It is also possible to use inventoryLevel(inventoryItemId) to get access to inventory without access

  • Example 2:
    Marketing activities with no marketing access

    even though it is possible to ask for more this is the basic query I used. Note it doesn't say access denied.
    query{marketingActivities(first:100){edges{node{id,title, createdAt, budget{total{amount}}}}}}

  • Example 3:
    Publications and api keys(I suspect app access makes you see api keys but still)

    Query I used:
    query{publications(first: 100){edges{node{name, id, supportsFuturePublishing, app{apiKey}}}}}

Impact

This means the graphql can be used to disclose information about other parts of the store that a low permissions user shouldn't have access to.

Best,
Eray

activities.message:
Thank you for your report, and sorry for the long wait.

It's intentional that store locations are accessible to all apps and users. However, marketing activities and publications were meant to be limited to particular API access scopes and user permissions.

We'll get back to you soon regarding a bounty payout.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report, and sorry for the long wait.

It's intentional that store locations are accessible to all apps and users. However, marketing activities and publications were meant to be limited to particular API access scopes and user permissions.

We'll get back to you soon regarding a bounty payout.

activities.message: Thanks for triage @clayton and I don't mind the wait as i'm sure you guys got a lot of reports during the event and I submitted this pretty late.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for triage @clayton and I don't mind the wait as i'm sure you guys got a lot of reports during the event and I submitted this pretty late.

activities.message: Thanks again for this report, we're awarding 500$ with a 3x bonus for being a graphql bug, for a total of 1500$.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks again for this report, we're awarding 500$ with a 3x bonus for being a graphql bug, for a total of 1500$.

activities.message: Woah thanks for the 3x. I look forward to working with you guys through the public program in the future.
activities.markdown_message: Woah thanks for the 3x. I look forward to working with you guys through the public program in the future.

activities.message:
Hi again @emitrani and sorry for the delay; as you can imagine we had a lot on our plate after H1-514. We've now updated our GraphQL permissions checks, so we're closing off this report.

For your example 1 there's no change; by design, store locations are accessible to all users regardless of permissions. For example 2, Marketing and Discounts permission is now required for access to marketing activities. For example 3, Products permission is now required for access to publications.

Thanks again for your report, and we look forward to hearing from you again soon!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi again @emitrani and sorry for the delay; as you can imagine we had a lot on our plate after H1-514. We've now updated our GraphQL permissions checks, so we're closing off this report.

For your example 1 there's no change; by design, store locations are accessible to all users regardless of permissions. For example 2, Marketing and Discounts permission is now required for access to marketing activities. For example 3, Products permission is now required for access to publications.

Thanks again for your report, and we look forward to hearing from you again soon!

activities.message:
Hi @clayton,

I don't think you are completely done with this report given the new changes to how application permissions work. If requested I can send a new report as well but here is what I've observed:

Since I don't have a Shopify Plus store I can't fully test this but I have a hunch. 

We know that only account owner is allowed to access  Exchange Marketplace app 
{F407770}

However if given access to apps or only graphql app a user will be able to grab the token for the app through gql queries like `{appInstallations(first:100)   {edges{node{id, launchUrl, app{apiKey, features}}}}}` notice the account doesn't have access to app launch url. 
{F407769}

This is why I think the per user app permissions can be bypassed by graphql app as when it was designed anyone who had access to that graphql would have access to any other application. 

Notice no required access prompt in docs:

{F407771}

You can either warn users graphql app gives permission to all other apps or implement finer access control. 

Let me know what you think.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @clayton,

I don't think you are completely done with this report given the new changes to how application permissions work. If requested I can send a new report as well but here is what I've observed:

Since I don't have a Shopify Plus store I can't fully test this but I have a hunch.

We know that only account owner is allowed to access Exchange Marketplace app

However if given access to apps or only graphql app a user will be able to grab the token for the app through gql queries like {appInstallations(first:100) {edges{node{id, launchUrl, app{apiKey, features}}}}} notice the account doesn't have access to app launch url.

This is why I think the per user app permissions can be bypassed by graphql app as when it was designed anyone who had access to that graphql would have access to any other application.

Notice no required access prompt in docs:

You can either warn users graphql app gives permission to all other apps or implement finer access control.

Let me know what you think.

activities.message: @emitrani If you're talking about the `apiKey` value, that's just an identifier, not an authentication token.
activities.markdown_message: @emitrani If you're talking about the apiKey value, that's just an identifier, not an authentication token.

I need a partner shop to test it fully. Any chance you can give it to my wearehackerone email?

As far as I can tell we can't access publications through the app but I'm thinking someone without access to app x can still request it through graphql and need partner to test that. We can get information about app pricing, any errors given by the app etc if this works. Here is the query I was trying with a user who will only have access to the graphql api.

{appInstallations(first:100) {edges{node{id,publication{name}, launchUrl, app{apiKey, features, pricingDetails, published, feedback{messages{message}} }}}}}

Note with recent changes publication{name} will return several errors like

 "message": "access denied",
      "locations": [
        {
          "line": 1,
          "column": 45
        }
      ],
      "path": [
        "appInstallations",
        "edges",
        4,
        "node",
        "publication"
      ]

but we can get information like:

 "node": {
            "id": "gid://shopify/AppInstallation/75431936022",
            "publication": null,
            "launchUrl": "https://emitrani.myshopify.com/admin/apps/google-shopping-2",
            "app": {
              "apiKey": "a78e004f44cded1b6998e7a6e081a230",
              "features": [
                "Easily sync your products",
                "Run a Google Shopping Campaign",
                "Track your campaign results"
              ],
              "pricingDetails": "Free to install",
              "published": true,
              "feedback": {
                "messages": [
                  {
                    "message": "Google Shopping is disconnected because your Merchant Center account has been suspended."
                  }
                ]
              }
            }
          }
        },

With an app user doesn't have access to:

 "node": {
            "id": "gid://shopify/AppInstallation/75493900310",
            "launchUrl": "https://emitrani.myshopify.com/admin/apps/exchange-sell-your-shopify-store",
            "app": {
              "pricingDetailsSummary": "Free to install",
              "apiKey": "96bb4269bedec4d9e67ceebfee9e1bf7",
              "features": [],
              "pricingDetails": null,
              "failedRequirements": [],
              "published": false,
              "feedback": null
            }
          }

activities.message: Some fields might be empty because of a lack of activity no errors were given to query `{appInstallations(first:100) {edges{node{id, launchUrl, app{pricingDetailsSummary, apiKey, features, pricingDetails, failedRequirements{action{url, title}}, published, feedback{messages{message}, link{url}} }}}}}` even though user shouldn't have access to exchange app.
activities.markdown_message: Some fields might be empty because of a lack of activity no errors were given to query {appInstallations(first:100) {edges{node{id, launchUrl, app{pricingDetailsSummary, apiKey, features, pricingDetails, failedRequirements{action{url, title}}, published, feedback{messages{message}, link{url}} }}}}} even though user shouldn't have access to exchange app.

activities.message:
> I need a partner shop to test it fully.

If you haven't already done so, you can sign up for a partner account here:

https://app.shopify.com/services/partners/signup/whitehat

You'll then be able to create development stores through that account. Does that get you what you need?

activities.message:
That feature is only available in Shopify Plus stores. We're currently sorting out a way to give hackers access to these features and will get back to you soon.

If you happen to find any further GraphQL issues (whether in that feature or elsewhere), please open a report in our main program (https://hackerone.com/shopify).
